entry.title: Cool Python Modules
entry.content:
Life is short, I use Python.

Python Modules

  • urllib2: extensible library for opening URLs
  • tweepy: a easy way to use twitter API
  • subprocess
  • shlex: The shlex class makes it easy to write lexical analyzers for simple syntaxes resembling that of the Unix shell
  • Scrapy: a framework for crawling web sites.
  • networks: a framework to study social network.

entry.title: Build VTK on Ubuntu
entry.content:
VTK is an open source framework for 3D computer graphics. I tried to build it on my Ubuntu systems, but failed for several times. I followed
and modified this scripts to build it successfully.

Download

Clone with git:

Configure

Qt Setup

VTK requires QT. I used Qt5 at first, but failed to install denali. I succeed with using QT4.

  • Download qt offline installer for linux:

  • Install to a separate directory, for example mine is installed at: $HOME/QT

  • Configure VTK with the following options

If CMake is not installed, You can install CMake by following Installing CMake. And If you have CMake errors, such as:

It’s a CMake missing modules directory discussed in Stackoverflow. Following below scripts to solve:

  • vi ~/.bashrc
  • edit .bahsrc by adding: export PATH=$PATH:/usr/bin:/bin
  • source ~/.bashrc

Another error is related to QT5, It shows that CMake cannot find my QT5 library.

Fixed it with following in /path/to/VTK/GUISupport/QT/CMakeLists.txt:

Methods to install Qt4, can be viewed here, remember to use “make install” after “make”.

  • mkdir qt-4.8.6-build && cd qt-4.8.6-build
  • wget http://download.qt-project.org/official_releases/qt/4.8/4.8.6/qt-everywhere-opensource-src-4.8.6.tar.gz
  • tar xzf qt-everywhere-opensource-src-4.8.6.tar.gz
  • cd qt-everywhere-opensource-src-4.8.6
  • make

Then in the VTK build directory, configure VTK with the path to the Qt build

Some errors such as:

>
Could NOT find Qt4 (missing: QT_QMAKE_EXECUTABLE QT_MOC_EXECUTABLE
QT_RCC_EXECUTABLE QT_UIC_EXECUTABLE QT_INCLUDE_DIR QT_LIBRARY_DIR
QT_QTCORE_LIBRARY)

Possible solutions:

  1. Add the path to the directory containing the qmake executable to your PATH environment variable (i.e. export PATH=/path/to/qmake/dir/:PATH under linux). Remember use source after configuration.
  2. Set the cmake variable QT_QMAKE_EXECUTABLE to the full path of the qmake executable (i.e. cmake /path/to/CMakeLists.txt -DQT_QMAKE_EXECUTABLE=/path/to/qmake/executable/dir/)
  3. Set the QT_QMAKE_EXECUTABLE in your CMakeCache.txt or using ccmake/cmakegui

Build

Once CMake finishes successfully configuring, use make inside the build directory.

Install it to a system-wide location:

Good Luck.

entry.title: Introduction to Heap
entry.content:
heapq - Heap queue algorithm

heapq is a standard library in Python, documentation is here: heapq.

heapq maintains a min-heap. As we know min-heap is a binary tree for which parent node has a value less than or equal to any of its children. This implementation can use arrays. If the parent node’s index is k, the left child will be 2k+1, and the right child will be 2k+2, counting element from 0.

Functions

It provides following useful functions, detailed information can by found in the documentation.

  • heapq.heapify(x): transform list x into a heap, in-place, in linear time

  • heapq.push(heap,item): push the value item onto the heap, maintaining the heap invariant

  • heapq.pop(heap): pop and return the smallest item from the heap, maintaining the heap invariant. To access the smallest item without popping it, use heap[0]

  • heapq.pushpop(heap,item): push item onto the heap and return the smallest item from the heap. It runs more efficiently than heappush(heap,item) followed by a separate call to heappop(heap).

  • heapq.nlargest(n,iterableItems): return a list with the n largest elements from the dataset defined by iterableItems.

  • heapq.nsmallest(n,iterableItems): return a list with the smallest elements from the dataset defined by iterableItems.

Examples

Use Min-Heap to find the k largest(smllest) elements in an array

We can use heapq.nlargest() and heapq.nsmallest() functions to find the k largest/smallest elements in an iterable list.

What’s the idea behind these functions?

Procedures:

  • Build a Min Heap of the first k-elements (array[0] - array[k-1]). O(k)
  • Find the k-largest: for each element( after the k-th element in the array from k to n-1), compare it with the root: if the element is greater than the root then push this element onto this heap, else ignore it. O((n-k)log(k))
  • Find the k-smallest: for each element, compare it with the root, if the element is smaller than the root then push this element onto this heap, else ignore it. O((n-k)log(k))
  • Finally, heap has k largest/smallest elements and root of heap is the k-th largest/smallest element.

Time complexity: O((n-k)log(k) + k) without sorted output. If sorted output is needed then O(((n-k)log(k) + k )+ klog(k)) = O(nlog(k) + k).

Build your own binary heap

Binary Heap Implementation

updates can be viewed here updates
entry.summary: heapq

entry.title: Delete Punctuation in Sentences
entry.content:
Delete Punctuation in Sentences

  • string.punctuation

String of ASCII characters which are considered
punctuation characters in the C locale.

  • string.translate(s, table[, deletechars])

Delete all characters from s that are in deletechars (if present),
and then translate the characters using table, which must be a 256-character
string giving the translation for each character value, indexed by its ordinal.
If table is None, then only the character deletion step is performed.

Reference

  • Code
  • Documentation
entry.summary: <h3 id="Delete-Punctuation-in-Sentences"><a href="#Delete-Punctuation-in-Sentences" class="headerlink" title="Delete Punctuation in Sentence

entry.title: Introduction to Binary Search Tree
entry.content:
Binary Search Tree

Definition

Binary search tree is a node-based binary tree data structure which has following properties:

  • The left subtree of a node contains only nodes with keys less than the node’s key
  • The right subtree of a node contains only nodes with keys greater than the node’s key
  • The left and right subtree each must also be a binary search tree

Implementation of Binary Search Tree

  • Description of Binary Search Tree Search and Insert Operation

  • Description of Binary Search Tree Delete Operation [Use the minmum value node in the right part to replace current node to be delted, if it has left and right child nodes]

My Source code can be viewed here: Githup

Advantage of Binary Search Tree

  • Search, insert, and delete opreations are O(log(n)).
  • Get all keys in sorted order by just doing traversal of BST.
  • Doing order statistics, finding closest lower and greater elements, doing range queries are easy to do with BSTs.
entry.summary: Binary Search Tree

entry.title: Usage of Subprocess Module in Python
entry.content:
subprocess module in python

The subprocess module allows you to spawn new processes, connect to their input/output/error pipes, and obtain their return codes. It intends to replace several older modules and functions such as: os.system, os.spawn, os.popen, popen2 and commands.

python document: subprocess - subprocess management.

Running via the shell

Above are basic usages.

The first item in list is the executable and rest are its command line arguments.

Both call and check_call can return the return code after running the command. The difference is check_call raises a CalledProcessError if the return code is non-zero.

check_ouput can run command with arguments and return its output as a byte string.

With shell setting to True, we can pass the commands as a string not a list. The program actually gets executed is the OS default shell, /bin/sh on linux and cmd.exe on windows. This can be changed with the executable argument.

reference

The ever useful and neat subprocess module
entry.summary: subpr

entry.title: Power your Githup Pages with Hexo
entry.content:
Hexo is a very powerful blog framework, which can be applied to your own github pages.

Requirements

  • Node.js
  • Hexo
  • Github

Node.js

Download Source code of Node.js

Read the readme file, and build:

  • ./configure
  • make
  • sudo make install

Then remember to update npm by:

Other ways to install Node.js: nvm to install Node.js

Hexo

  • Change to your favorite directory, create folder:
  • Install dependency:
  • Create static files:
  • Run Server

Open your web browser, type localhost:4000 to view your local blog. Use Ctrl-C to stop the server.

Deploy Hexo to Github

Create your own repository: demo, name is: zhenv5.github.io.

  • Edit _config.yml file in your Hexo directory.

If error (for example can not find git) occurs, install hexo-deployer-git in the root folder of Hexo:

Save file and deploy changes:

Generate and deploy commands can also be used as:

Some bugs may occur: From hexo系列教程：（二）搭建hexo博客

>
在github部署完成之后，马上访问可能出现404错误，这是正常的，（最多）等待十分钟左右就可以访问了。如果还不行，那很可能是 github 发送给你的验证邮件你没有打开看，据多方反映，验证后就没问题了。
如果在hexo d之后出现fatal: ‘username.github.io’ does not appear to be a git repository，一是检查 repo 的名字是否合乎规范、是否含有大写字母、config.yml 中的 deploy 配置是否正确，二是把 git bash 关掉，重新打开再执行命令。

You can also preview your blog locally, by assigning a port:

The default open port is 4000, whey you type:

Sometimes, it may remind you that port 4000 is used. In case that you can assign port 5000 to Hexo Server. And use localhost:5000 to preview your blog.

Post blogs

  • Set categories in your post:
  • Set tags in your post:

In the head of your post, it may look like this:
entry.summary: Hexo is a very powerful blog framework, which can be applied to your own github pages.
